snippet: Owners of the Chevrolet car complained about power steering failures, locks opening and closing and doors jamming shut long before the car became known for having a deadly ignition defect.
abstract: New York Times analysis of state databases and court records shows that long before Chevrolet Cobalt became known for having deadly ignition defect, it was already seen as a lemon; in more than 120 instances, General Motors was forced under state lemon laws to buy back faulty Cobalts, pay settlements to owners or let them trade in the cars.

byline.original: By DANIELLE IVORY and REBECCA R. RUIZ
byline.contributor: Rachel Abrams, Susan C. Beachy, Bill Vlasic and Kitty Bennett contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: Owners of the Chevrolet car complained about power steering failures, locks opening and closing and doors jamming shut long before the car became known for having a deadly ignition defect.

headline.main: Cobalts Were Seen as Lemons From Start, State Data Shows
headline.print_headline: Cobalts Were Seen as Lemons From Start, State Data Shows
